answers.author: Harry Kenworthy
answers.text:
By applying Lean principles to reduce costs/wastes, frees up additional capacity to provide more service.  In the case of Fire and Police and other city departments, this creates the ability to spread a wider net of service, if possible, and engage surrounding communities in service, thereby collecting revenues for providing those services (sort of a regionalization effort).  Of course, this is dependent on the towns being serviced willing to relinquish some of their own current service control.  Net-net it lowers costs.  Also, look at school systems in cities.  Many times there is an elected school board with their own budget and an elected City council with their respective budget, with a bunch of duplicated functions between both of them that could be consolidated (it doesn't collect revenues, but it does free up more money for the classroom and having less students/teacher).  Of course beyond this, Lean can be applied to both budgets to, once again, reduce costs/wastes, while improving service/capacity.  When politics are involved: 
1. The lack of political will and  
2. Thinking about what's best for me as a politician vs. what's in the best interest for the greater good of the served community many times prevails to the detriment of the overall system.
